Fig. 1 (A) Performance of different machine-learning model on test set. Performance of the XGB model: (B) Validation set and (C) Test set. Feature importance sorting based on SHAP value (D). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (A) Performance of model in validation set when Leaving One Out method for cross validation; (B) Importance of atomic features based on SHAP value; (C) Potential enhancements for catalytic activity by combing elements with Mn. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Catalytic activities (A, C), N2 selectivity (B, D) (1000 ppm, 30,000 mL·g−1·h−1) of prepared catalysts. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 SEM of Mn (A) and Cr(III)-Mn together with EDX mappings of Mn, Cr, and Si (B). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XPS Mn 2p (A), Cr 2p (B), O 1 s (C), and leaching concentration of Cr6+ (D) from Cr-Mn. Note: Cr-Mn-NH3 stood for sample treated under NH3 at 150°C for 1 h; Cr-Mn-SCR stood for sample carried out SCR at 150°C for 1 h. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 DRIFTS of Mn (A), Cr(III)-Mn (B), and Cr(VI)-Mn (C) when NH3 reacted with pre-adsorbed NOx; DRIFTS of Mn (D), Cr(III)-Mn (E), and Cr(VI)-Mn (F) when NOx reacted with pre-adsorbed NH3. R. China ⁎ Corresponding author. Traditional catalyst design includes trial-and-error and orthogonal methods. However, these processes usually require large number of experiments to get an optimized formula. Machine learning was applied in designing effective catalyst for selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of nitrogen oxide (NOx). Catalyst formulas and their activities in previous reports were collected and fitted by extreme gradient boosting algorithm and explanatory algorithm-SHapley Additive exPlanations. Mn-Cr coupling was predicted to be the most effective for SCR among various couplings, which was then proved by experimental results. SCR activity of Mn catalyst was increased from 50.3 % to 85.0 % at 150°C after the catalyst was loaded by Cr. Furthermore, machine learning and experimental characterizations revealed that the big total electronegativity of Cr resulted in bidentate nitrate bonding one cation with two oxygens, which was the most active NOx-derived intermediate during SCR. This work is in favor of catalyst design and catalytic-species recognition at the same time. Graphical Abstract Keywords Machine Learning Selective Catalytic Reduction, Catalyst Design Electro-negativity Chromate Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Traditional strategy for developing the catalyst is based on experience and ‘trial and error’ [1], which consumes a lot of resources. With the rapid development of artificial intelligence in recent years, data mining and machine learning are gradually applied to the design and development of various materials [2], such as catalysis [3]. In brief, machine-learning method gets “knowledge” from a large number of catalyst data, throws away “garbage”, and thus guides experiment [4,5]. For example, artificial neural network targeted CO conversion, and effectively predicted the catalyst for water-gas shift reaction [6]. A generalized prediction model was established by artificial neural network to predict the rate constant of TiO2 during wastewater photodegradation [7]. The variables, which had great influences on the catalyst, were obtained to facilitate the design of catalyst [4–7]. Nitrogen oxide (NOx) is one general atmospheric pollutant, which results in various hazards, such as acid rain and human respiratory diseases [8]. Thus, modern countries usually set strict discharging limit for NOx. At present, selective catalytic reduction (SCR) is the most useful method to remove nitrogen oxides from over discharging [9,10]. For a typical SCR, one catalyst accelerates the reaction between nitrogen oxide and reductant (such as ammonia), producing harmless N2 and H2O [11,12]. The catalyst is the key of SCR and attracts the most attentions in the field of SCR. Vanadium supported TiO2 is a commercial catalyst, and effectively removed NOx at around 250°C [13,14]. Manganese-based catalysts removed NOx at a temperature below 200°C [15,16]. General transition metals all showed SCR activity, higher or lower. Worldwide researchers are trying to develop new catalysts with high activity together with low cost. Metal modification usually enhances the SCR performance [17,18], and the single-factor investigation is a typical method. Orthogonal design is a method using orthogonal tables to arrange and analyze multi-factor experiments in order to find optimal level combination [19,20]. For example, this method analyzed the effects of metal species, calcination temperature, calcination time, and metal-load quantities on the SCR performance of a coke-based catalyst [21]. Response Surface Methodology (RSM) uses multiple quadratic equations to fit the relationship between factors and reference variables, finding the best parameters [22,23]. RSM optimized SCR performance of MnOx/γ-alumina catalysts [24]. In another investigation, RSM optimized SCR performance of V/TiO2, and indicated that calcination temperature was the most important factor [25]. Although the number of experiments was reduced by above methods, it’s our speculation that development time and cost for SCR catalyst would be significantly decreased by a machine-learning design and analysis. Therefore, this paper applied machine learning to screen out an effective SCR catalyst by recognizing atomic-scale features of elements. First, experimental data were collected from previous literatures so as to predict SCR performances. Second, catalysts were synthesized, and applied in SCR to verify the prediction. Third, the optimized formula was characterized to verify the predication from atomic-scale reorganization. Above investigations revealed the reason why certain elements were more inclined to show a better SCR activity than others. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Machine-learning sorting of main elements 200 experimental data were collected from previous works. The selection criteria were catalysts, which contained widely-investigated catalytic elements (Co, Sn, Zr, Cu, W, V, Ti, Nb, Eu, Gd, Sb, Nd, Mn, Ce, and Fe) in SCR and were published in recent ten years. Both the conversion as well as test conditions (such as gas hourly space velocity and reaction temperature) were featured to predict active components, which performed better at lower temperatures and explained the mechanism through atom-scale features. All the selections were supplied in the supporting file (Data.xlsx). These data were made up of features and targets. Table S1 shows the lists in the Supporting Information. The features included calcination temperature (CT, °C), calcination time (time, h), preparation method (PM), active components (at%), support type (ST), gas hourly space velocity (GHSV, h−1)，reducing agent NH3 content (ppm), moisture content (vol%), sulfur dioxide content (ppm) and reaction temperature (T, °C). The target was NO conversion (%). All these data were normalized, which were described in the supporting information, and then fitted by four different machine-learning models, including linear least-square (LLS), support vector regression (SVR), artificial neural network (ANN), and XGBoost (XGB) [26–28]. The data were randomly divided into two subsets, 80 % of which were used as training set to train the model, and 20 % as test set to test the generalization ability of the model. The specific parameters of the model are listed in Table S2. Pearson correlation coefficient (R) and root mean square error (RMSE) were calculated by Eqs. (1) and (2), and evaluated the performances of four different models. (1) R = ∑ i = 1 n y i − y ̅ y ˆ i − y ˆ ̅ ∑ i = 1 n y i − y ̅ 2 ∑ i = 1 n ( y ˆ i − y ˆ ̅ ) 2 (2) RMSE = 1 n ∑ i = 1 n y i − y i ˆ 2 In these two equations, y i is the true value, y ̅ is the average of the true values, y ˆ is the predicted value of the model, and y ˆ ̅ is the average of the predicted values. Interpretive algorithm SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) analyzed features that affected the catalytic activity [29]. The SHAP value was based on the Shapley value, which was a concept in game theory. The SHAP was aimed to explain the model predictions by calculating the contribution of each feature to the model predictions. It turned a black box model of machine learning into a transparent and interpretable model. The mathematical description was expressed by Eq. (3). (3) g z ′ = Ø 0 + ∑ j = 1 M Ø j In this equation, g is the interpretation model, M is the input characteristic number, Ø is the Shapley value of each feature, and Ø 0 is a constant, which is generally the average of the target performance. 2.2 Machine-learning screening of auxiliary metals In order to screen out effective auxiliary metals, eleven atomic-scale characteristics were calculated by the formulas in Table 1, including total atomic radius (T_R), atomic radius difference (diff_R), total valance electron (T_VEC), valance electron difference (diff_VEC), total electro-negativity (T_PE), electro-negativity difference (diff_PE), total atomic volume (T_V), atomic volume (diff_V), total atomic mass(T_M), and atomic mass difference (diff_M). For example, the T_PE was the sum up of the product of elemental ratio (ai) and elemental electro-negativity (PEi) involving all the catalytic elements in one catalyst. The used data were supplied in the supporting file (Data-atom feature.xlsx). 2.3 Catalyst preparations In order to check whether an additional metal resulted in an enhanced effect, a batch of manganese supported SiO2 was firstly prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method [30], and denoted as Mn. Second, a hydrothermal method modified the Mn to increase the interaction between manganese and co-doping metals [31]. In detail, 10 g of the Mn was immersed in 100 mL of nitrate solution (0.25 mol·L−1) for 8 h. The mixture was transferred to an autoclave, and treated at 180°C for 12 h. The solid was separated by filtration, washed 5 times by deionized water, dried at 110°C, and finally calcined at 400°C for 3 h. The obtained solid was denoted as M-Mn (M = Fe, Cr, Zn, Cu, Co and Ni), indicating the cation species in the nitrate solution. Furthermore, during the synthesis of Cr-Mn, 50 % and 100 % (molar amount) of Cr(NO3)3·9 H2O was replaced by K2Cr2O7, in which Cr was hexavalent. The obtained Cr(VI)-containing catalysts were denoted as Cr(III)0.5Cr(IV)0.5-Mn and Cr(IV)-Mn. In this case, the above Cr-Mn was also denoted as Cr(III)-Mn for an easy comparison. All above catalysts were milled to 200 meshes. In one catalyst, Mn content was 1.5 mmol·g−1 and the content of the additional metal was 1.3 ± 0.06 mmol·g−1, which were detected by an inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES, Prodigy7, Leeman) after digestion. 2.4 Catalytic activities A fixed-bed reactor detected catalytic activities of the above catalysts [32]. Inflow gas contained 1000 ppm of NO, 1000 ppm of NH3, and 5 % of O2 (Ar balance), which flowed through catalyst at a GHSV of 30,000 mL·g−1·h−1. All the gases were controlled by mass flow meters (Beijing Seven-star Electronics Co., Ltd.). Residual concentration of NOx (NO, NO2, and N2O) was detected by a FTIR gas analyzer (MultiGas 2030-HS High Speed, MKS). Catalytic activity was expressed by the conversion of NOx. Catalytic selectivity was calculated by the formation rate of N2. 2.5 Characterizations Crystal morphology (XRD) was measured by X-ray diffraction (X’Pert3 MRD) equipped with α (= 0.154 nm) radiation. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was obtained using a monochromatic Al-Kα source and a charge neutralizer (wscalab, Thermo Scientific). N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were performed on an BELSORP-max (MicrotracBEL, Japan). Specific surface areas were measured by BET (Brunauer–Emmett–Teller) method. Total content of Cr was detected by ICP-AES. Cr(VI) concentration was analyzed by using a UV–vis spectrophotometer method (GB7467–87). Micro-morphologies were examined by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) using a MERLIN compact machine (ZEISS, Germany) equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDX). In-situ Diffuse Reflection Fourier Transform Infrared (DRIFTS) was carried out on a FTIR spectrometer (Therm Scientific, Nicolet IS10) [33]. After a catalyst was set in the chamber, N2 purged it for 30 min to clean residual air. A spectrum was collected at 150°C as the background. NH3/NO+O2 was then adsorbed at 150°C for 30 min before NO+O2/NH3 flowed into the cell and reacted with the pre-adsorbed species. All spectra were recorded by overlapping 32 scans at a resolution of 4 cm−1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Main element sorting Fig. 1A shows the performances of four models in the test set. A bigger R and a lower RMSE indicated a better performance. XGB attained the R value of 0.87, bigger than LLS (0.80), SVR (0.82), and ANN (0.82). At the same time, XGB had the lowest RMSE of 6.66 %, lower than LLS (8.44 %), SVR (7.32 %), and ANN (8.03 %). Fig. 1 B and 1 C shows the distribution of XGB between the predicted value and the real value in the validation set and the test set. The closer the slant line was, the more accurate the prediction was. According to these results, the prediction was more accurate at the data with higher NO conversions (> 90 %) together with considering the influence of GHSV, and this part of data was more important to find better catalysts. Fig. S1 compares the predictions of other models. Fig. 1 D shows the sorting of feature importance. Among all the investigated elements, Mn played the biggest role at the low-temperature SCR. Sulfur dioxide and water both affected the catalytic activity [34,35]. Although support type (ST) and calcination temperature (CT) were also important, their weights were inferior to those key elements. After all, Mn was chosen as the main element. 3.2 Auxiliary metal screening Features of auxiliary metals were screened by calculating the correlation coefficient between each feature (Pearson correlation coefficient was used in this paper). Fig. S2 shows the heat map. Features with high correlation (R > 0.95) were thus removed, and the remaining atomic features were diff_VEC, T_PE, diff_PE, and diff_M (Fig. S3). The super parameters of XGB were determined by using Leave One Out cross validation on the whole data set. Fig. 2 A shows the performance of the model on the validation set. Most data were well fitted. R reached 0.91 and RMSE was 4.4 %. Feature importance was further analyzed based on SHAP value. The T_PE had the greatest influence on the catalytic activity (Fig. 2 B). According to this result, typical transition metals were screened ( Fig. 3 C). A deeper color indicated a potential better auxiliary metal. Obviously, Fe and Cr formed an enhanced catalyst with Mn. In comparison to other efficient auxiliary candidates (such as Ce and Re), these elements had advantages of low cost and plenty source. 3.3 Catalytic activities Fig. 3A shows the catalytic activities of synthesized catalyst. Generally, an auxiliary metal enhanced the SCR activity [36]. Mn removed 50.3 % of NO at 150°C. After loading an auxiliary metal, the activity was increased to 91.9 % (Fe), 85.0 % (Cr), 51.4 % (Zn), 56.8 % (Cu), 71.5 % (Co), and 62.0 % (Ni). Fe-Mn and Cr-Mn showed better performances than others. This was consistent with the machine-learning prediction (Fig. 2). On the contrary, most of the auxiliary metals decreased the N2 selectivity (Fig. 3 B). Mn attained a selectivity of 91.9 % at 150°C, which was decreased to 87.2 % (Fe), 86.1 % (Zn), 80.4 % (Cu), 89.7 % (Co), and 90.0 % (Ni), except for Cr-Mn (96.3 %). Thus, Cr improved the catalytic activity and N2 selectivity at the same time. When 50 % and 100 % of Cr(III) was replaced by Cr(VI), the catalytic activities were further increased (Fig. 3 C). Cr(III)0.5Cr(VI)0.5-Mn and Cr(VI)-Mn both removed > 88 % of NO at 150°C. However, Cr(VI) loaded Mn showed inferior selectivity than Cr(III)-Mn and Mn (Fig. 3 D). In addition, Cr(III)0.5Cr(VI)0.5-Mn showed a stable conversion in a long-time performance (Fig. S4). Even under a higher GHSV of 40,000 mL·g−1·h−1 (Fig. S5), Cr(III)0.5Cr(VI)0.5-Mn still removed 75.4 % of NO at 150°C. Therefore, Cr(VI) had a better activity than Cr(III) when cooperating with Mn. 3.4 Role of Cr(VI) All catalysts showed a main phase of SiO2, which had diffractions at 20.9°, 26.7°, 28.7°, and 50.2° (Fig. S6) [37]. Besides, diffractions of MnO2 were also recognized. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of these catalysts had a similar pattern (Fig. S7), indicating a type IV with a H3 hysteresis loop according to IUPAC classification [38]. This was a typical character of a mesoporous material [39]. Table S3 lists the textural properties, including specific surface area (28.55 – 58.70 m2·g−1), pore volume (0.09 – 0.17 cm3·g−1), and pore size (11.43 – 14.73 nm). Obviously, these were similar values. Fig. 4 A and 4 B shows the SEM of Mn before and after co-loading Cr(III), the micro-morphologies were similar amorphous particles. In addition, all elements, including Mn, Cr, and Si were well dispersed with each other (Fig. 4 B). Mn 2p curves were fitted into three species ( Fig. 5 A), including Mn2+ (640.3 eV), Mn3+ (641.4 eV), and Mn4+ (643.1 eV) [40,41]. Their percentages are listed in Table 2. Cr-Mn contained 20 % of Mn2+, 40 % of Mn3+, and 40 % of Mn4+. When it was treated under NH3 at 150°C, the percentage of Mn2+ was increased to 28 %. In comparison, if the Cr-Mn was applied in SCR at 150°C. The percentages of Mn species maintained the same values. Hence, NH3 reduced the valence and NOx recovered the reduced valence. Cr 2p was made up of Cr3+ (575.9 eV) and Cr6+ (579.0 eV) (Fig. 5 B) [42,43]. Cr-Mn contained 55 % of Cr3+ and 45 % of Cr6+. Although only Cr3+ was used during preparation, partial Cr3+ was oxidized to Cr6+. When Cr-Mn was treated under NH3, the percentage of Cr6+ was decreased to 39 %. If being used in SCR, the percentages hardly changed. This was similar to the tendency of Mn valences. O 1 s curves were fitted into lattice oxygen (Oα, 529.2 eV), surface oxygen (Oβ, 531.4 eV), and hydroxyl oxygen (Oγ, 532.7 eV) (Fig. 5 C) [44,45]. However, their percentages maintained same values under NH3 and SCR. These catalysts were washed by hydrochloric acid, and Cr6+ concentrations were detected in the leaching (Fig. 5 D). In the first circle, 4.1 mg·L−1 of Cr6+ was detected. This value was decreased to 1.5 mg·L−1 if the catalyst was treated under NH3. This value was increased to 3.6 mg·L−1 after SCR. In the next two circles, the same tendency was observed, which was consistent with the result in Fig. 5 B. When Mn, Cr(III)-Mn, and Cr(VI)-Mn adsorbed NOx, a similar pattern were observed ( Fig. 6 A, 6 B, and 6 C), including three nitrate species [46–48]. Bidentate nitrate bonded two cations with two oxygens, and showed one vibration at 1604 cm−1 (v B1 ). When bidentate nitrate bonded one cation with two oxygens, the structure showed one vibration at 1540 cm−1 (v B2 ). In comparison, when monodentate nitrate bonded one cation with one oxygen, the structure showed one vibration at 1294 cm−1 (v M ). After NH3 reacted with these species, the intensity of v B2 was decreased along with time. At the same time, the intensity of adsorbed NH4 (1467–1511 cm−1) was increased. In other words, NH3 was adsorbed on adsorptive sites, which was pre-occupied by NOx and consumed by NH3. As for v B1 and v M , their intensities showed no obvious decreases. Thus, these two species were not active for SCR. When Mn, Cr(III)-Mn, and Cr(VI)-Mn adsorbed NH3, a similar pattern were also observed (Fig. 6 D, 6 E, and 6 F), including three nitrate species. Adsorbed NH3 showed two vibrations at 1610 and 1250 cm−1 [46–48]. NH4 species were located at 1459 cm−1 and NH2 species were observed at 1530 cm−1. Note that NH2 intensities of Cr(III)-Mn and Cr(VI)-Mn were stronger than that of Mn. After NOx reacted with these species, the intensities of all these species were decreased. At the same time, one vibration was formed step by step at 1530 cm−1, which was attributed to v M1 . Besides, v B and v M2 were also observed in Mn. On the contrary, these two nitrates were not formed in Cr(III)-Mn and Cr(VI)-Mn. Fig. 7 shows the role of Cr6+ in Cr-Mn during SCR. The regeneration of adsorptive sites played an important role in SCR. According to Fig. 6, the consumption of adsorbed NOx was important to the release of adsorptive sites. However, only when NOx was adsorbed by one cation with two oxygens (v B2 ), the formed NOx species were consumable. Cr6+ had a significant electronegativity, which means that it easily formed v B2 with NOx. Note that Mn4+ also had a big electronegativity and formed v B2 . However, when Mn4+ was reduced by NH3 (Fig. 5), the formed Mn2+ bonded NOx by v B2 and v M . In comparison, Cr6+ was only reduced to Cr3+, which still had a considerable electronegativity. The electronegativity explanation was consistent with the result of machine learning in Fig. 1 and 2. As a result, the Cr-doped Mn showed a better SCR activity than the Mn (Fig. 3). 4 Conclusion In this work, machine-learning method was used to predict potential effective catalyst formula for effective SCR at low temperature. First, the main element was sorted, and then auxiliary metal was screened. As a result, Mn-Cr coupling showed to be one optimized formula, which was supported by the experimental verifications. After Cr was loaded on the Mn, SCR activity was increased from 50.3 % to 85.0 % at 150°C. The machine learning suggested that total electronegativity of one element played a quite important role in determining SCR activity. XPS and DRIFTS characterizations revealed that Cr resulted in bidentate nitrate (adsorbed NOx) bonding one cation with two oxygens. This configuration was the most active NOx-intermediate at low-temperature SCR. This work is a successful example of catalyst design and mechanism revelation by machine learning. coredata.dc:description: Traditional catalyst design includes trial-and-error and orthogonal methods. However, these processes usually require large number of experiments to get an optimized formula. Machine learning was applied in designing effective catalyst for selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of nitrogen oxide (NOx). Catalyst formulas and their activities in previous reports were collected and fitted by extreme gradient boosting algorithm and explanatory algorithm-SHapley Additive exPlanations. Mn-Cr coupling was predicted to be the most effective for SCR among various couplings, which was then proved by experimental results. SCR activity of Mn catalyst was increased from 50.3 % to 85.0 % at 150°C after the catalyst was loaded by Cr. Furthermore, machine learning and experimental characterizations revealed that the big total electronegativity of Cr resulted in bidentate nitrate bonding one cation with two oxygens, which was the most active NOx-derived intermediate during SCR. This work is in favor of catalyst design and catalytic-species recognition at the same time.
